flametree 0.0.1
  • Reference

Generate the data specifying a flametree

Source: R/grow.R
flametree_grow.Rd

Generate the data specifying a flametree

flametree_grow(
  seed = 286,
  time = 6,
  scale = c(0.6, 0.8, 0.9),
  angle = c(-10, 10, 20),
  trees = 1,
  seg_col = NULL,
  seg_wid = NULL,
  shift_x = NULL,
  shift_y = NULL,
  n_shoot = NULL
)

Arguments

seed

Integer-valued seed for the random number generator
time

Number of generations to run the iterative process
scale

Vector of possible values for the "size rescaling" at each iteration
angle

Vector of possible angle changes (in degrees) at each iteration
trees

Number of trees to generate
seg_col

Function to control the segment colour
seg_wid

Function to control the segment width
shift_x

Function to control horizontal jitter
shift_y

Function to control vertical jitter
n_shoot

Function to control tree branching

Value

A tibble with the following columns: coord_x, coord_y, seg_deg, seg_len, seg_col, seg_wid, id_time, id_path, id_step, id_leaf, id_tree

The two "coord" columns specify the locations of a point. The "id" columns uniquely identify each point: id_time specifies the generation, id_path identifies each segment, and id_step contains the three values (0, 1 or 2) for the points that define each segment. The segments consist of two end points (0 and 2) and one "control" point (1) that is used to define a Bezier curve. Finally, id_tree is a numeric identifier indicating which tree the row belongs, and id_pathtree is a character variable that pastes the id_path and id_tree identifiers to create an identifier that is unique for each path in each tree.

The three "seg" columns provide summary information about each segment: seg_len is the length of the segment, seg_col is a value used to colour the segment, and seg_wid is a size parameter used to define the width of the segment

Examples

flametree_grow()

#> # A tibble: 381 x 12
#>    coord_x coord_y id_tree id_time id_path id_leaf id_pathtree id_step seg_deg
#>      <dbl>   <dbl>   <int>   <int>   <int> <lgl>   <chr>         <int>   <dbl>
#>  1   -1.11    0          1       1       1 FALSE   1_1               0      90
#>  2   -1.11    0.5        1       1       1 FALSE   1_1               1      90
#>  3   -1.11    1          1       1       1 FALSE   1_1               2      90
#>  4   -1.11    1          1       2       2 FALSE   1_2               0      80
#>  5   -1.11    1.3        1       2       2 FALSE   1_2               1      80
#>  6   -1.00    1.59       1       2       2 FALSE   1_2               2      80
#>  7   -1.11    1          1       2       3 FALSE   1_3               0     100
#>  8   -1.11    1.45       1       2       3 FALSE   1_3               1     100
#>  9   -1.26    1.89       1       2       3 FALSE   1_3               2     100
#> 10   -1.00    1.59       1       3       4 FALSE   1_4               0      90
#> # … with 371 more rows, and 3 more variables: seg_len <dbl>, seg_col <dbl>,
#> #   seg_wid <dbl>
flametree_grow(time = 10)

#> # A tibble: 6,141 x 12
#>    coord_x coord_y id_tree id_time id_path id_leaf id_pathtree id_step seg_deg
#>      <dbl>   <dbl>   <int>   <int>   <int> <lgl>   <chr>         <int>   <dbl>
#>  1    1.22    0          1       1       1 FALSE   1_1               0      90
#>  2    1.22    0.5        1       1       1 FALSE   1_1               1      90
#>  3    1.22    1          1       1       1 FALSE   1_1               2      90
#>  4    1.22    1          1       2       2 FALSE   1_2               0      80
#>  5    1.22    1.3        1       2       2 FALSE   1_2               1      80
#>  6    1.33    1.59       1       2       2 FALSE   1_2               2      80
#>  7    1.22    1          1       2       3 FALSE   1_3               0     100
#>  8    1.22    1.45       1       2       3 FALSE   1_3               1     100
#>  9    1.07    1.89       1       2       3 FALSE   1_3               2     100
#> 10    1.33    1.59       1       3       4 FALSE   1_4               0      90
#> # … with 6,131 more rows, and 3 more variables: seg_len <dbl>, seg_col <dbl>,
#> #   seg_wid <dbl>
